importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The planned exhibition date of the Picasso painting at CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain, was October 9, 2025, making this date critical to the timeline of the incident.
The disappearance was discovered just before the exhibition opened, on the Friday before October 9, during delivery and unpacking procedures.
The article was updated on this date, and the police investigation was officially reported to CNN on this day.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The delivery and unpacking of artworks occurred over a short time frame, with delivery scheduled for the Friday before October 9 and unpacking beginning at 8:30 a.m. Monday, October 10.

keyTakeAways: A Picasso painting titled 'Still Life with Guitar' (1919) went missing during delivery to a temporary exhibition at CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain.
The artwork was insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000), indicating high value and likely significant interest from art thieves.
The painting was delivered via van, moved to a freight elevator, and then unpacked under video surveillance with no apparent incidents during the weekend.
The disappearance was noticed during the unpacking process on Monday, October 10, 2025, after the delivery crew had signed off on the delivery.
Spanish police have launched an investigation and have reported the work to international databases of stolen artworks, though no international cooperation is currently underway.
Picasso's works are frequently targeted by thieves due to their high market value and cultural significance, as seen in past recoveries in the Netherlands, Greece, and Belgium.

namedEntities.name: Pablo Picasso
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A renowned Spanish artist, known for his significant contributions to modern art and for creating highly valuable and sought-after paintings.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The painting in question is attributed to Pablo Picasso, and its disappearance highlights the vulnerability of his works to theft due to their high market value.

namedEntities.name: Still Life with Guitar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1919 gouache painting by Pablo Picasso, measuring 12.7 cm by 9.8 cm.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This specific painting is the central object of the missing artwork incident, which occurred during transit to an exhibition in Granada.

namedEntities.name: CajaGranada Cultural Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cultural center located in Granada, Spain, that was supposed to host the exhibition of the Picasso painting.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The painting was scheduled to be displayed at this center, and its disappearance was detected during the unpacking process there.

namedEntities.name: Granada
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in southern Spain, where the CajaGranada Cultural Center is located.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the exhibition and the site of the theft is in Granada, Spain, making it a key geographical context for the incident.

namedEntities.name: Spanish police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Law enforcement agency in Spain responsible for investigating the disappearance of the artwork.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Spanish police are currently investigating the theft and have reported the work to international databases.

namedEntities.name: Transportation company
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A company that delivered the artworks to the cultural center in Granada.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The delivery was carried out by this company, and the entire process—including van transport and elevator movement—was part of the timeline of the incident.

namedEntities.name: Dutch art detective
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A detective in the Netherlands who recovered a stolen Picasso painting in 2019.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Past recovery cases involving Picasso paintings illustrate a pattern of theft and recovery, showing that Picasso artworks are a consistent target for thieves.

namedEntities.name: Netherlands
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country where a Picasso painting was recovered in 2019.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The recovery of a Picasso painting in the Netherlands demonstrates a global pattern of theft and retrieval of such high-value artworks.

namedEntities.name: Greece
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country where a Picasso painting was recovered in 2021.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The recovery of a Picasso painting in Greece reinforces the global threat and recurring nature of Picasso-related art thefts.

namedEntities.name: Belgium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country where a Picasso painting was found in 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The discovery of a stolen Picasso painting in Belgium shows that such thefts are not isolated and occur across Europe.

namedEntities.name: Portrait of Dora Maar
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A 1938 Picasso painting worth $28 million, recovered in 2019.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This painting's recovery underscores the high value and vulnerability of Picasso's works to theft and recovery efforts.

namedEntities.name: Head of a Woman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Picasso painting recovered in 2021 in Greece.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its recovery illustrates the recurring pattern of theft and recovery of Picasso's works in different countries.

namedEntities.name: Landscape with a Mill
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Piet Mondrian painting recovered in 2021 in Greece.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This painting was stolen during the same heist as a Picasso piece, showing that high-value art collections are common targets.

namedEntities.name: Tête
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Picasso painting recovered in 2024 in Belgium.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its discovery highlights the persistence of Picasso artwork theft and the global reach of such crimes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 1919 gouache painting by Pablo Picasso titled 'Still Life with Guitar' went missing during its delivery to a temporary exhibition at the CajaGranada Cultural Center in Granada, Spain, just before the exhibition was set to open on October 9, 2025. The artwork, insured for 600,000 euros ($700,000), was delivered via van, transported through a freight elevator, and unpacked under video surveillance, during which no incidents were recorded. The painting was discovered missing during the unpacking process on Monday, October 10, prompting Spanish police to launch an investigation. The case has been added to international databases of stolen artworks, though no international cooperation is currently underway. This incident is part of a broader pattern of theft targeting Picasso’s works, as seen in previous recoveries in the Netherlands, Greece, and Belgium, where high-value paintings such as 'Portrait of Dora Maar', 'Head of a Woman', and 'Tête' were also stolen and later recovered.
title: Picasso painting goes missing en route to exhibition
